abstract: Minimalist sculpture meets aerodynamics in a new show at London's Haunch of Venison.
snippet: Minimalist sculpture meets aerodynamics in a new show at London's Haunch of Venison.
lead_paragraph: In the last several months, the British designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby of BarberOsgerby have once gain proven their impressive versatility. They've produced an inexpensive, wildly practical plastic chair for Vitra and directed a group of students from the ECAL in Lausanne, Switzerland, to create a playfully luxe group of objects based on a traditional Baccarat goblet. And they've been on fire - pardon the pun - since they were named in June as the designers of the 2012 Olympic torch, a sleek, triangular form with 8,000 perforated circles that represent each of the people who will carry the torches. (Yes, 8,000 torches - one for each torchbearer - will be produced.) But their latest effort is not about design in the expected sense.

headline.main: Less Is More | Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby
